From: Cisco IOS Configuration Fundamentals Command Reference
FuncDef: To enter global configuration mode, use the **configure terminal** command in privileged EXEC mode.
CLIs: Cisco IOS Releases 12.3(14)T and Subsequent Releases:
Cisco IOS Releases 12.2(33)SRC and Subsequent Releases:

ParaDef.Info: Time in minutes (1-120) for which to wait for confirmation.

Examples: The following example shows how to enter global configuration mode and lock the Cisco IOS software in exclusive mode:
Enter configuration commands, one per line. End with CNTL/Z.
ExtraInfo: Use this command to enter global configuration mode. Note that commands in this mode are written to the running configuration file as soon as you enter them (using the Enter key/Carriage Return).After you enter the **configure terminal** command, the system prompt changes from `<router-name>#` to `<router-name>(config)#`, indicating that the router is in global configuration mode. To leave global configuration mode and return to privileged EXEC mode, type **exit** or press **Ctrl-Z**.To view the changes to the configuration you have made, use the **more system:running-config** command or **show running-config** command in user EXEC or privileged EXEC mode.Configuration LockingThe first user to enter the **configure terminal lock** command acquires the configuration lock (exclusive configuration mode).

RelatedCmds.description: Specifies the device and filename of the configuration file from which the router configures itself during initialization (startup).
Enables locking of the configuration file for single user access.
Saves the running configuration as the startup configuration file.
